awd_titl_txt: Friction Extrusion Process and Equipment Development for Production of High Value Materials from Low-Cost Precursors
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding for the development of the friction extrusion process and associated equipment to enable direct production of high-value materials (such as titanium wires) from low-cost precursors (such as powders or machining chips) with reduced energy consumption. Friction extrusion die and process chamber design will be studied. Experiments and numerical simulations will be carried out to develop an in-depth understanding of the scientific principles and physical mechanisms operating in the friction extrusion process. Friction extrusion experiments will be carried out to gain a physical understanding of the process and equipment, such as the effect of extrusion die and chamber design on power consumption and quality of the produced wire. Computational models will be created to simulate the extrusion process in order to investigate issues (e.g. full-field material flow pattern and thermal history) not approachable experimentally. Validation and visualization experiments will be designed and performed to provide measurements of material position, velocity and temperature for validating simulation model predictions, so that computational models can be utilized reliably for process design and optimization purposes.

If successful, the results of this research can be used to enable the design, optimization and utilization of the friction extrusion process for the energy-efficient production of high-value materials from low-cost precursors and for recycling machining wastes (chips). The friction extrusion process has the potential to greatly reduce energy requirements for the production of titanium wire feedstock by eliminating costly vacuum melting and billet casting. Wires produced from this process could be used as feedstock for additive manufacturing processes or as filler wires for niche welding applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to develop a fundamental understanding of the friction extrusion process, in which high-value wires are produced from low-cost precursors (e.g. machining chips) using heat generated by friction. A combination of experiments and modeling/simulation work were carried out.

 

Aluminum alloy wires were produced using the friction extrusion process from precursors such as machining chips. The effects of process parameters on the microstructure and mechanical properties of the wires were characterized. To understand material flow patterns in the wires and correlate them to wire properties, marker inserts in the precursors were used, and the produced wires were sectioned and then the positions of the marker materials in the wires were measured using optical microscopy. The mechanical properties of wires were characterized by using indentation hardness tests.

 

Frictional heating in the friction extrusion process plays a critical role in softening the precursor material and then in extruding the material into wires. To understand the amount of temperature rise due to frictional heating, thermocouples were inserted into a number of drilled holes in the process tool, the process chamber and the back plates and the temperatures at the tips of the holes were measured as a function of time.

 

To visualize the material flow pattern during friction extrusion, a model friction extrusion process was developed, in which the process chamber and the extrusion die were built using a transparent material. A transparent yet highly viscous fluid was selected as the precursor, and marker particles were added to the fluid to allow direct observation and recording of the marker particle movement using a specialized 3-D digital image measurement system.

 

To provide an understanding of the heat transfer and material flow phenomena inside the friction extrusion process chamber, which is in general not directly observable experimentally, computational models of the friction extrusion experiments were developed and simulations of the heat transfer and material flow events were carried out using computational fluid dynamics and computational solid mechanics methods. Simulation predictions were then validated using measurements of the temperature field at select locations, measurements of the marker particle movement in the visualization experiments, and measurements of marker positions in the wires in the friction extrusion experiments of aluminum alloys. Good agreements between predictions and measurements were achieved. The simulation results and experimental measurements together provide a more complete understanding of the friction extrusion process.

 

The friction extrusion process has many potential applications. In terms of reducing materials waste and energy consumption in manufacturing processes, the friction extrusion process is a potentially efficient method for producing wires from waste metals (e.g. maching chips) without melting. The friction extrusion process can also be used to produce wires with custom alloy composition from precursors such as powders. The wires can be used as welding filler wires or as wires for additive manufacturing processes.  This project has demonstrated the viability and potential of this friction extrusion process and provided an understanding of the physical phenomena involved in this process. The results of this research provide a scientific basis for further development of this promising manufacturing process.


Last Modified: 11/18/2016
Modified by: Xiaomin Deng
